reasoning: The critique targets an important methodological pillar of the essay: using VNM-style cardinalization plus large-scale value comparisons while also flagging systematic intuition failures (scope insensitivity, hedonic-treadmill style effects). If that pillar were genuinely incoherent, it would weaken a meaningful portion of the argument, though it would not wholly collapse the position (many of the essay’s ‘fussiness’ claims are structural and don’t strictly depend on raw intuitions). The refutation is only partial: VNM axioms need not be ‘calibrated on intuitions’ in the way alleged (they are constraints on a preference ordering and a representability theorem), and acknowledging bias does not by itself make subsequent formal comparisons incoherent—one can argue our intuitions are unreliable and then propose more scope-sensitive formalisms as a corrective. Still, there is a real tension the critique highlights about what, concretely, anchors the cardinal scale and intertheoretic comparisons if our intuitive judgments are unreliable. The critique is mostly correct but overstates the incoherence claim. It is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: Scope insensitivity undermines the intuitions anchoring the formal framework
